msgSnippet: Hi Mark Actually, I think this sounds more as an addition to a matcher framework like hamcrest rather than an addition to JUnit itself. What do you think? see

Hi Mark

Actually, I think this sounds more as an addition to a matcher fra=
mework like hamcrest rather than an addition to JUnit itself. What do you t=
hink? 

see also: https://github.com/hamcrest/JavaHamcrest/issues/82

all t=
he best

Stefan


> Am 04.10.2015 um 19:55 schrieb Mark Silvis masilvis22@g=
mail.com [junit] <junit@yahoogroups.com>:
> 
> I would like to contribute t=
o JUnit, and I think I have a good idea for a feature. I=E2=80=99ve found t=
hat it would be nice to have assertions that explicitly supported Java 8=E2=
=80=99s Optional class. I=E2=80=99m thinking something along the lines of a=
ssertEmpty() and assertPresent(). Would such an addition be welcomed?
> 
> =
Thanks,
> Mark
> 

--Apple-Mail-8FBC46B4-DF91-44F5-A5F3-FF5893B100C8

an style=3D"display:none"> </span>



    <div id=3D"ygrp-text">
     =
 
      
      <p>I would like to contribute to JUnit, and I think I have a=
 good idea for a feature. I=E2=80=99ve found that it would be nice to have =
assertions that explicitly supported Java 8=E2=80=99s Optional class. I=E2=
=80=99m thinking something along the lines of assertEmpty() and assertPrese=
nt(). Would such an addition be welcomed?<br>
<br>
Thanks,<br>
Mark<br>
</p=
>

    </div>
